message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s normal physical exam, parents’ normal heights, and delayed bone age suggest a diagnosis of constitutional growth delay, which is a common cause of short stature in adolescents. Familial short stature would have already manifested in childhood and not lead to delayed bone age. Congenital adrenal hyperplasia would manifest as ambiguous genitalia and virilization in girls, but the patient has normal sexual development. Growth hormone deficiency would have additional symptoms like dry skin, constipation, and headaches, which are not present in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history and physical examination do not suggest any specific chronic disease, ruling out options C and D. Normal sexual development and parents of normal height suggest that the patient is not affected by familial short stature. Delayed bone age and the growth chart indicate that the patient has constitutional growth delay, a condition where the child grows at a normal rate but at a later time compared to their peers.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s normal physical examination, normal vital signs, and delayed bone age suggest that the cause of his short stature is constitutional growth delay, which is a benign condition in which a child’s growth rate is temporarily slower than average but eventually catch up during puberty. Familial short stature is unlikely because both parents are of normal height. Congenital adrenal hyperplasia causes salt-wasting and ambiguous genitalia but the patient did not present with these symptoms. Growth hormone deficiency can cause short stature, but the normal physical examination and normal vital signs make it less likely.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history and physical examination do not suggest any disease or abnormality. Analysis of his growth charts and the delayed bone age suggest constitutional growth delay, which is a common cause of short stature in adolescents. Familial short stature is ruled out since the parents are of normal height. Congenital adrenal hyperplasia and growth hormone deficiency usually present with other symptoms like weight gain/loss, constipation, dry skin, and headache, which are not present in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s normal physical examination, along with his history and X-ray results, suggests that he has constitutional growth delay, which is a normal variant of growth that usually resolves spontaneously. Familial short stature and Congenital adrenal hyperplasia usually have a family history and/or other symptoms. Growth hormone deficiency would have abnormal growth hormone stimulation test results.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s physical examination and history suggest a delayed bone age and his parents are of normal height, which is consistent with a constitutional growth delay. Familial short stature is usually not associated with delayed bone age. Congenital adrenal hyperplasia and growth hormone deficiency usually present with other symptoms such as weight loss, constipation, dry skin, and headache, none of which are present in this patient’s history.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s delayed bone age and normal physical examination suggest constitutional growth delay, which is a temporary delay in growth and eventual normal adult height. Familial short stature usually has a family history of short stature, and there is no indication of Congenital adrenal hyperplasia. Growth hormone deficiency would have more significant growth retardation and micronutrient deficiency can lead to a variety of symptoms such as constipation, dry skin, and headaches, which are absent in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history, physical examination and delayed bone age suggest that the most likely cause is constitutional growth delay. Congenital adrenal hyperplasia and growth hormone deficiency would have other specific symptoms and signs. Familial short stature would not have delayed bone age.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has normal physical examination and normal sexual development, which suggests that hormonal abnormalities are unlikely to be the cause of the short stature. The normal birth weight and height and delayed bone age suggest that there was no congenital or genetic causes for the short stature. Therefore, the most likely cause is Constitutional Growth Delay, which is a normal variance in the rate of physical development that typically leads to normal adult height but manifests as delayed puberty and delayed bone age during adolescence.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a delayed bone age and his parents are of normal height, which suggests that the most likely cause of his short stature is constitutional growth delay. Familial short stature is ruled out because the patient’s parents are of normal height. Congenital adrenal hyperplasia may cause short stature, but it is usually accompanied by other physical and biochemical abnormalities. Growth hormone deficiency is also a possible cause of short stature, but its association with a delayed bone age is not as strong as constitutional growth delay.
